arm_group.description: Leisure time physical activity (LTPA): Exercise intensity: 70% of maximal oxygen uptake (VO2 max); Energy expenditure: Females: 1600 kcal/week; Males: 2100 kcal/week
Leisure time physical activity (LTPA): Exercise intensity: 50% VO2 max; Energy expenditure: Females: 1600 kcal/week; Males: 2100 kcal/week

Bicycling to/from work/school/university. No requirements for exercise intensity; Energy expenditure: Females: 1600 kcal/week; Males: 2100 kcal/week; Avg distance per day Females 9-15 km; Males 11-17 km

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of present randomized controlled trial is to evaluate the health effects of physical
      activity in transport and leisure time domains of everyday life and to develop durable
      physical activity regimens, i.e. to go from lifestyle intervention to daily lifestyle
      routine, in overweight individuals.

      Subjects will be randomized to 1 of 4 groups. 1: Vigorous intensity leisure time physical
      activity, 2: Moderate intensity leisure time activity, 3: Active commuting by bicycle, or 4:
      a non-intervention control group

clinical_study.brief_title: Active Commuting To Improve Well-being and Health in Everyday Life

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy

          -  No engagement in habitual structured physical activity

          -  Body mass index 25-35 kg/m2

          -  Body fat percentage >32% for women and >25% for men

          -  Maximum oxygen uptake (VO2max) <40 ml O2/kg/min for women and <45 ml O2/kg/min for
             men

          -  Ethnicity: Caucasian

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Chronic use of medicine

          -  Smoking

          -  Fasting plasma glucose > 6,1 mmol/L

          -  Blood pressure > 140/90 mm Hg

          -  Abnormal resting and working ECG

          -  Parents or siblings with diagnosed type 2 diabetes

          -  For women: Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) concentration > 35 milliunits/ml,
             pregnancy or planning of pregnancy within the coming year

facility.name: University of Copenhagen, Department of Biomedical Sciences

clinical_study.official_title: Active Commuting To Improve Well-being and Health in Everyday Life

other_outcome.description: Adherence to the exercise protocol as measured using heart rate and global positioning system monitors will be assessed and individually adjusted continuously over the course of the exercise intervention

primary_outcome.description: Measured using the hyper-insulinemic euglycaemic clamp
primary_outcome.measure: Peripheral insulin sensitivity (glucose clearance ml/min/kg fat-free mass/nM insulin)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in peripheral insulin sensitivity at 3 months

secondary_outcome.description: Fasting plasma glucose, 1- and 2-hour plasma glucose and glucose area under the curve measured during an oral glucose tolerance test
Fasting plasma insulin, homeostasis model assessment insulin resistance and measures of central insulin sensitivity  derived from an oral glucose tolerance test
Measured using indirect calorimetry and an incremental bicycle protocol
Visceral intrabdominal and subcutaneous fat mass determined by magnetic resonance imaging
As measured by high density lipoprotein, triglycerides, waist circumference, blood pressure, mean arterial pressure, fasting glucose and composite metabolic syndrome scores

1: Coagulation: Fibrinogen, Tissue factor(TF), prothrombin fragment 1+2. 2: Fibrinolysis: Tissue type plasminogen activator(tPA:AG), Plasminogen activator inhibitor type 1(PAI-1:AG). 3: Endothelial cell function: von Willebrand factor(vWF), Tissue factor pathway inhibitor (TFPI). 4: Inflammation: C-Reactive protein.
Measured using questionaries (SF-36), semi-structured interviews and observations
secondary_outcome.measure: Health related quality of life and other psycho-social outcomes

secondary_outcome.description: Measured using dual x-ray absorptiometry, height, weight, waist and hip circumference, sagittal abdominal height
Sleep duration and quality measured using accelerometers, logs and questionaires (Pittsburgh sleep quality index and Epworth sleepiness scale)
